text: - Hello, and welcome to this

"AWS TechShift: Migrate &
Modernise" video miniseries.

This video series is aimed at
independent software vendors
who are currently running on premise
and are looking to migrate to the cloud.

It's also aimed at those
that are looking to modernize

an existing architecture to
become more cloud native.
Through these five short videos
we will explore the benefits

of migrating to AWS and
the techniques involved

in modernizing a typical
monolithic architecture.

We will do this by introducing
a case study application,

and through each of the
videos we'll dive deeper

into a specific element of
the architecture to improve.
In the first introduction video,

let's again think about
the benefits of migration
and introduce our case study.
(upbeat music)
So as an ISV, how will you benefit
from moving your application to the cloud?
Increase agility and performance.
Focus your time on adding new features
and differentiating your application

rather than managing
infrastructure and data centers.
We invent on your behalf at AWS

with services such as
AI, ML, and analytics

available on demand
whenever you are ready,
allowing easy experimentation
and reducing the time to market.
Nearly unlimited scalability.
With AWS, you can scale your application

as your business grows
and onboard new customers

without having to worry
about capacity challenges,
such as planning and buying new hardware
for your data center.
You can scale within your local region
or go global within minutes.
Improve reliability.

Multiple availability
zones within each region
allows you to architect your application

for high availability
and improve the uptime
for your end users.

Lower costs: AWS benefits
from economies of scales

and our experience in innovation
allows us to find new ways
to deliver technology more efficiently.

We pass these cost savings
onto you as our customers.

You also get the
elasticity with the cloud,
meaning you only pay for what you use.
So if your application has spiky

or unpredictable usage patterns,
this allows you to save
over provisioning for peak.
Security is job zero at AWS.

And with AWS, you can
build on the most secure

global infrastructure, knowing
that you always own your data
including the ability to encrypt it,
move it and manage retention.
AWS also supports more security standards

and compliance certifications
than any other offering,
including PCI, DSS, GDPR, and FIPS 140-2.

Now let's introduce our example
corporation, which we'll use

as a migration case study for
the rest of the video series.

So what application will we
be migrating and modernizing?
The application is a simple photo gallery

where users can upload,
tag and search photos.

It is developed using
Node.js and JavaScript
and has been built to replicate a business
that has been running for many years.

As a result, parts of the
application are quite basic.

Some parts are hard coded and
some parts are more advanced
as the application has evolved over time.
The application has a HTTP web front
which is a single page application,
and everything runs from a single server,
including the database.
Our unicorn photo gallery application
exists on premise today on a single server

in a data center and end users
access it over the internet.
If we were to move this server into AWS

in a lift and shift model, we'd
first look to use a service

called Amazon Elastic
Cloud Compute, or EC2.
With EC2, we can run our application

as is on a virtual Linux
or Windows instance,

running in the cloud, paying
per hour that it runs.
This is okay, it's simple and it works,
but there are a few challenges.
Firstly, there is a single instance
in a single availability zone,
meaning that there's no resilience

should the availability
zone or the instance fail.

We also can't scale
the database separately

from the web tier, as they're
all on a single instance.
Ideally we would want to be able

to scale the web tier
horizontally by adding more nodes.

We also have to have the EC2
instance running all the time,
no matter what the traffic demand is.

We should scale based on
demand as well as offload

some of the requests to static
content, such as images,
to a caching layer.
Throughout the rest of the video series
we will look to improve this architecture.

We will introduce more subnets
in more availability zones

and improve security
using private subnets.

We will also separate
out the database layer
using a service called Amazon Aurora.
We will then scale out the web tier

using an auto scaling
group and a load balancer.
Finally, we'll move the static web content
to Amazon S3 as an object store
and front this with Amazon CloudFront
as a content delivery network.
Amazon CloudFormation will also be used

to define our infrastructure
resources as code.
And that's it for the introduction.

Join us in the next video where
we'll look at landing zones
and the VPC structure.
(upbeat music)
